user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in the provided function are invariant. The function contains only conditional statements whose controlling expressions depend on runtime values: the Mode comparisons (if (Mode == ...), else if (Mode == ...)) depend on the Mode parameter; the if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0) depends on the runtime result of shutdown(). There are no loops or conditionals using constant/compile-time-invariant expressions (e.g. if (1), while (0), or a do-while with a constant false) that would trigger Rule 14.3. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET/OS_ObjectIndexFromToken and the table indexing use the token’s obj_idx at runtime, so they are not invariant either. Therefore, there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for Rule 14.3.
